This favors the soil for agricultural production due to the existence of abundant water underground.

loans.use: to purchase a vaporizer (for use after massages and hair coloring), and sculpting scissors (scissors for thinning out the hair)

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa is married with 3 children. She is 57 years old and lives in Romarate, Aurora Zamboanga del Sur. Felisa sells charcoal to earn a living and she has been in this business for 3 years. 

Every month, Felisa earns 7,000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 10,000 PHP to purchase additional coconut shells to make charcoal for charcoal trading. (Charcoal is made from coconut shells or firewood.) Felisa sells the charcoal to her "suki" buyer and others in the community.

Felisa has been a member of GDMPC for 2 years. In the future, Felisa hopes to have another "baril" container where she burns the coconut shells for charcoal, so she can produce more charcoal. For now she has only one.


GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

GDMPC people empowering people

loans.use: purchase coconut shells to make charcoal

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.ru: Бахтиёр проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 42 года. Женат. Детей не имеет. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам он предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области он два года. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины, чтобы предоставить безопасную услугу.
texts.en: Bakhtiyor lives in the Hamadoni district.  He is 42 years old, married and has no children.  His wife is a homemaker.  Bakhtiyor provides a taxi service and has been in this business for two years.  He is requesting this loan to make repairs to his car in order to provide a safe service.

loans.use: to make repairs to his car

loans.name: Duo Luchando Por La Vicion Group

texts.es: Duo Luchando por la Vision.este duo esta formado por dos personas muy buenas y responsables,uno de ellos es don,Oscar Samuel,de 50 años quien se dedica a la venta y confeccion de ropa para dama,caballero,y niño.el inicio su venta hace 12 años,nos comenta que este negoscito le a ayudado mucho con el sustento de su hogar,y le da gracias a Dios por que le a dado la oportunidad de tener este negocio,el esta solicitando este credito para la compra de tela y ropa variada,y en diferentes estilos,ya que sus clientes le piden nuevos estilos,al igual que don Pedro,porque el tambien se dedica a la misma actividad que don Oscar,el sueño de ellos es tener un local mas grande para obtener mejores ingresos, asi de esa manera ayudar a su familia.
texts.en: The communal bank "Duo Luchando por la Visión" is comprised of two very good, responsible people.  One of them is Oscar Samuel, 50, who makes and sells women's, men's and children's clothing.  He started his sales business 12 years ago and says it has helped him support his family; and he gives thanks to God for the opportunity to have the business.  He is requesting a loan to buy fabric and varied clothing in different styles because his customers want new fashions.  Pedro is in the same business as Oscar and their dream is to one day have a larger shop and earn a better income so they can help their families.

loans.use: To buy women's, men's and children's  to sell.

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kamwenge in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past three years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her small store, which sells fruit and snacks. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more fruit for resale, and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and improve her family's quality of life. Scovia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land to build on. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has improved Scovia's future prospects by helping her learn how to run a business and learn how to write.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit for resale,

loans.name: Ernesto José

texts.es:
Don Ernesto es una persona emprendedora quien tiene su negocio de Cerrajería y venta de accesorios para celulares, el trabaja junto con su hijo en el mercado de la capital, el trabaja de lunes a sábados de las ocho de la mañana hasta las seis de la tarde.
El ha trabajado nueve prestamos con ceprodel y estos han sido para el negocio, gracias a  estos financiamientos el ahora cuenta con dos tramos y con dos tipos de actividades comerciales, ya que el anteriormente solo poseía el negocio de la Cerrajería.
Da gracias a ceprodel por los financiamientos que le ha brindado ya que ahora su negocio ha crecido. El es casado y con dos hijos pero solo una depende ya de el y esta se encuentra en secundaria.
texts.en:
Ernesto is an entrepreneur who has a locksmith business and sells cellular phone accessories. He works with his son in the capital city market place. He works from Monday through Saturday from 8:00 AM until 6:00PM. 

He has had nine business loans with Ceprodel and thanks to these loans he now has two small areas with two types of commercial activities where as before he only had the locksmith business.

He thanks Ceprodel for the loans provided to him since now his business has grown. He is married with two children but only one is dependent on his and he attends high school.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for his locksmith business

loans.name: Mindanella

texts.en:
Mindanella is 56 years old and lives in Sapang Ama, Sapang Dalaga. She is widowed with two children.

Mindanella has a business weaving Nipa palm leaves and earns approximately 3,500 PHP each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase housing materials for completion of her house.

Mindanella has been a member of PMPC for one year.

loans.use: to purchase housing materials (galvanized iron sheets, plywood, nails)

location.town: Calamba-Sapang Ama Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidenta

loans.name: Kilimo Bora A Group

texts.en:
Florence joined One Acre Fund in order to have more food production and improve agricultural skills to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Florence had a very good maize yield harvesting 17 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Florence was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Florence will educate her children and save for future use.

Florence is the facilitator of the Kilimo Bora A group. The photograph shows Florence with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer. Florence and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Florence and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Petronila Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Doña Petronila reside en el departamento de Masaya. Ella tiene 13 años de tener su propio negocio de elaboración de flores para todo tipo de ocasión, aparte que ella también tiene  su venta de productos  como hamacas, artesanía en barro, entre otros.  Por la temporada ella esta teniendo mas demanda por lo que se presentó a Ceprodel a solicitar un nuevo crédito. 

La señora Petronila  quiere invertirle más a su negocio para poder cubrir la demanda y por eso el crédito lo usará en la compra de hamacas, chinos, jarrones, tela, y las bellas flores para continuar ofertándolas.  

Ella comenta que gracias a la ayuda brindada por Ceprodel por medio de los créditos, ha podido salir adelante en su negocio y ha dado una mejor calidad de vida a su familia y quiere continuar con esto
texts.en: Petronila lives in the department of Masaya, Nicaragua. She has had her own business for 13 years selling flowers for every occasion, and she also sells products such as hammocks, artisan vases, and other items. She is experiencing high demand because of the Christmas season, so she is turning to Kiva partner Ceprodel to request a new loan. Petronila wants to invest more in her business to meet demand and plans to use the loan to purchase hammocks, vases, fabrics and pretty flowers so she can continue offering the products. She says that thanks to the support from the loans she has been able to make headway with her business and has improved her family's quality of life, and she wants it to continue.

loans.use: to purchase hammocks, vases, fabric and flowers.

loans.name: Juan Bautista Del Carmen

texts.es:
Juan Bautista es un señor de 49 años el cual vive con su familia en una comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Mollejones de Platanares, Pérez Zeledón. Mollejones es una comunidad ubicada a 150 kilómetros al sur de la Provincia de San José, la capital de Costa Rica. Se encuentra a 850 metros sobre el nivel del mar. Ahí se cultivan hortalizas, café y además se desarrollan otras actividades como la crianza de ganado de engorde y de cerdos. Existen también algunos proyectos de agricultura orgánica y hortalizas en hidroponía. Además de la agricultura en la comunidad hay talleres mecánicos, un supermercado, pequeños restaurantes (sodas) y una mueblería.

Desde hace algún tiempo Juan Bautista se dedica a su microempresa donde vende gorras, sombreros y camisetas. Inició este proyecto desde el año 2003 y los resultados han sido buenos, ya que ha tenido una gran aceptación en su comunidad y los ingresos que ha generado lo han ayudado a sacar adelante a su familia. Actualmente tiene seis maquinas para su negocio.

En estos momentos lo que desea Juan Bautista es solicitar un préstamo por ¢600,000 (seiscientos mil colones) para comprar más materiales para su taller, los cuales necesita para su proyecto. Con esto espera que su microempresa crezca y llegue a generar más ingresos para mejorar su condición de vida.  
Juan Bautista forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancruce una de las 150 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Como socio ha recibido un microcrédito que le han permitido crecer como microempresarios.
texts.en:
Juan Bautista is 49 years old and lives with his family in a rural community in Costa Rica called Mollejones de Patanares, Pérez Zeledón. Mollejones is located 150 kilometers south of the province of San Jose, the capital of Costa Rica. It is 850 meters above sea level. There, the people cultivate vegetables and coffee and also raise beef cattle and pigs. There are also some organic farming projects and hydroponic vegetable gardening (growing plants in water, without soil). In addition to agriculture, the community has mechanic shops, a supermarket, small restaurants (low-cost eateries) and a furniture store.

For some time, Juan Bautista has owned a small business where he sells caps, hats and T-shirts. He started his business in 2003 and the outcome has been good since he has been very well received in his community and his earnings have helped him to move his family forward. Currently he has six machines for his business.

Nowadays, Juan Bautista would like to request a loan of 600,000 colones to purchase more materials, which he needs for his shop. With this sum he expects his small business to grow and begin to generate more income so he can improve his living conditions.

Juan Bautista is part of the “Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancruce” Communal Bank, one of the 150 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. As a member, he has received a loan that has enabled him to grow as a small business man.

loans.use: to buy materials for his small business.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 37 years old, married to Chege, and they have been blessed with seven children. She has been buying and selling maize for the last two years, earning a monthly income of about KES 3,000.

She is borrowing her first loan of KES 25,000 from KADET, which she intends to use to purchase maize for resale. With the anticipated profits, she will expand her business.

Her hopes and dreams are to be a cereal distributor.

loans.use: To purchase maize for resale.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 27 years old, married, and has 2 children aged 5 and 10. In 2004, Rebecca established her soft 

drinks, water, and food provisions business. She began her business because she saw there was a need to help 

her husband provide income for the family. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about 470,000

 SLL every month from this business. 

She would like a loan of 3,000,000 SLL to purchase more stock such as sugar, milk, mayonnaise, sardines, water, soft drinks, and stationery for resale. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profit by approximately 500,000 SLL. Part of the profit will be reinvested in the business. 

In the future, Rebecca plans to educate her children up to university level. 

She thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: to purchase more stock such as, sugar, water, soft drinks and some stationery for resale.

loans.name: Luis Alonso

texts.en:
My name is Luis Alonso U., and I am a salesman. I have a small store in one of the busiest areas in my community. I have several years in this industry. With the income from sales at my store I am able to cover my family’s expenses, and other commitments. My idea is to offer new products at my little store, so I can improve my sales, and therefore my income.

Loan Use: Purchase hair accessories, bracelets, earrings, necklaces, rings, shoes, nail polish, lipstick, and others.

Mi nombre el Luis Alonso U., son comerciente tengo un pequeño negocio en uno de los lugares mas transitados de mi comunidad, cuento con varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de negocio el que me genera ingresos para los gastos familiares y otros compromisos, mis ideas es de surtir mas minegocio para mejorar la ventas y por ende mis ingresos.

loans.use: Venta de ganchos para el pelo, colas, pulceras, aritos,collares, anillos, zapatos,esmaltes, Listip y otros

loans.name: Malu

texts.en: Malu, 35, married, joined the SPBD microcredit programme in 2005, although she started her fishing business already five years ago. Her husband and two other boys from the same village are also involved in the business; however, Malu is the one who sells fish at the Savalalo Fish Market. Her last loan helped her very much - she was able to purchase a deep freezer and two gallons of coolers. With the help of an additional loan, she intends to buy more coolers to store more fish.

loans.use: To purchase four (4) additional coolers for storing fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand her household products shop business

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mrs. Vann L. H. is 21 years old and lives in Pray Veng with her husband (pictured here with a pig cage on the back of his moto) and their infant child.  They work together purchasing and raising pigs.  When the time comes and the pigs are mature, they sell them to the market.  This business gives them about $3/day of income on average, although it depends on the size of the pigs and the market rate when they come to maturity.  This loan will be used for Mrs. Vann L. H. to purchase more pigs.

loans.use: To purchase pigs

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr:
Mrs. Akoua K., 42, is married and mother of five children. She sells little smoked fish to earn a living. Her husband is a driver but he does not have a car to use which means that Akoua is the sole breadwinner for the family. Because she lacks capital to invest in her micro-enterprise, she often runs out of fish and is not able to satisfy her customers’ needs. For that reason, Akoua is asking for a loan of US$ 500 which will allow her to buy more fish at a time and thus be able to keep her customers satisfied and coming back to her.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Agée de 42 ans, Madame K. Akoua est mariée et mère de cinq (5) enfants. Elle exerce comme activité la vente des petits poissons fumés. Son mari un chauffeur n’a pas de voiture à sa disposition ce qui fait que toutes les charges se reposent sur Madame K. Akoua. Par manque de moyens, elle est souvent confronté à la rupture de stock et n’arrive pas à satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Pour remédier à cette situation, elle sollicite un crédit de $500 qui va lui servir de fonds de commerce pour pouvoir s’approvisionner en grande quantité et fidéliser sa clientèle.

loans.use: buying and selling little smoked fish  Achat et vente de petits poissons fumés

loans.name: Ni Made Tesni

texts.id:
Ni Made Tesni lives in Ekasari village, West Bali. Ni Made Tesni besides a housewife, also has a hooby raising pigs which she has done since Tesni got married. With a capital of Rp800,000 (about US$88), Tesni bought 1 mother pig, and after 6 months she gave birth to 8 piglets. Income from sales of piglets are Rp 250,000 (about $27.50)/pig. In 6 months Tesni sold the piglets for Rp2,000,000 (US$220) minus mother pig feed expenses of Rp 270,000 (about $30). Profit left for Tesni is about Rp200,000 ($22)/month. That profit is used to pay for family expenses. With her husband I Wayan Raka, Tesni lives in own land, and a quite permanent building, also all children are married. With the loan, she plans to repair her pig stalls, so that it would be larger and cleaner, so that her pig's health are maintained, and free of disease.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Made Tesni tinggal di Desa Ekasari, Bali Barat. Ni Made Tesni disamping sebagai ibu rumah tangga juga mempunyai kegemaran memelihara babi dan hobinya ini sudah ditekuni semenjak Tesni menikah. Dengan modal awal Rp. 800.000,- Tesni membeli 1 induk babi, dan setelah 6 bulan induknya melahirkan anak babi sebanyak 8 ekor. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dari penjualan anak babinya per ekor Rp. 250.000,-. Dalam 6 bulan Tesni mendapatkan penjualan anak babinya sebesar Rp. 2.000.000 dipotong biaya pakan induk sebesar Rp. 270.000.- Jadi Tesni mendapatkan peningkatan pendapatan sebesar Rp. 200.000.- per bulan. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dipakai untuk mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya , bersama dengan suaminya I Wayan Raka, Tesni tinggal di tanah sendiri dengan bangunan yang cukup permanen, dan anaknya sudah semua sudah menikah . Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, direncanakan untuk memperbaiki kandang babinya agar lebih luas dan bersih sehingga kesehatan babinya bisa terjaga dan terhindar dari penyakit.

loans.use:
To repair pig stall so that it would be larger and more hygienic

Memperbaiki kandang agar lebih luas hyeginis

loans.name: Zahara

texts.en:
My name is Zahara B.. I was born and brought up in a small town called Pattoki. But after I got married, I had to move to Lahore with my husband. Since then, I have lived in Lahore. I am a mother of five children: four boys and one girl.

My husband works at a government institute for a meager income. My eldest son is a rickshaw ( local three-wheeled taxi) driver. My son now plans to buy another rickshaw, which he will rent out to supplement his income. For this purpose we request a loan of $175.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda is 60-years-old and is a cheerful and active woman. She has copy machines with which she offers services to the general public, and she also has copying contracts with some well-known companies in the region. She and her husband, Severo, no longer have the responsibility of caring for their children, since they are professionals, have their own families, and live in different cities throughout the country. Both have the goal of putting their copy machines in place and maintaining them, with the aim of continuing their work with satisfaction. Let's offer Yolanda a breath of hope so she can accomplish her goals as soon as possible.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Yolanda de 60 años de edad, es una mujer jovial y súper activa, tiene sus máquinas copiadoras con los que brinda servicios al público en general, también hace contratos de copias con algunas empresas reconocidas en la zona.En compañía de su esposo el señor Severo ya no tienen responsabilidades con sus hijos, ya que los mismos son profesionales, se hicieron de familia y se encuentran radicando en las diferentes ciudades de su país.Ambos tienen una meta, implementar y realizar el mantenimiento respectivo a sus máquinas copiadoras a fin de seguir desempeñándose con satisfacción en esta su labor.Otorguémosles un aliento de esperanza a la señora Yolanda para que en el menor tiempo posible se cumpla sus propósitos.

loans.use: Expansion of her service space and maintenance of her copy machines

loans.name: Wambizzi B Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Rose is a 49 year old widow with nine children. She sells charcoal for a living. Rose usually earns shs 50.000 in profits each week. She wants to use the extra business profits to construct a house for the children and also re-invest in the charcoal business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

loans.name: Maybe Liz

texts.es:
Mrs. Maybe Liz L. Ramírez belongs to Grupo Mientras Tanto Yungay Hermosura. Her business is located in the town and province of Yungay, in the Ancash region. Her determination and spirit of working so that she can get ahead has allowed her to contribute towards the costs of her family. Her business is in a rented shop started with a previous loan of S. 300.00. She has grown her business and her earnings. With this loan of S. 500.00, repaid in four months, she will invest in the purchase of more basic necessities for cooking like rice, sugar, noodles, oil, and salt. Maybe Liz serves pensioners and customers who come to eat daily. She is 26 years old, has one five-year-old child and her husband has temporary work. With her earnings, she will support her husband and child and her goal is to continue to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Maybe Liz L. Ramírez, pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto Yungay Hermosura su negocio esta ubicado en la localidad de Yungay, provincia de Yungay, departamento de Ancash, su empeño y espíritu de trabajar para poder salir adelante le ha permitido aportar en los gastos de su familia, su negocio esta en un local alquilado es lo Con el crédito anterior de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, ha incrementado su negocio y sus ingresos. Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de mas insumos de primera necesidad para la elaboración de alimentos, arroz, azúcar, fideos, aceite, sal, la señora cuenta pensionistas y clientes que van a consumir diariamente Ella tiene 26 años, tiene un hijo de 5 años y su esposo tiene trabajo eventual, con los ingresos que tiene apoya a su hijo y esposo, su meta es seguir creciendo con su negocio.

loans.use: With a loan, she will buy basic ecessities for her restaurant.

loans.name: Taga 1 Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
After four weeks of rigorous business training, these four women of Taga 1, from the island of Savaii, passed their written test on the SPBD principles (business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee) in order to ensure their first group loan from SPBD. Over the next year, they will support each other in their individiual business developments to guarantee on-time payments.

Ana L., age 32, married, with three children, sells taro, tuamu and bananas, staples of the Samoan diet. Her husband and sons are experienced farmers. Her loan will be used to purchase a weed killing sprayer, a knife, knife sharpener, an axe, chemicals and a wheel barrow.

Kalameli Ufi L., age 25, married, with five children, and Leatuvai F., age 54, married, with six children, sell taro, bananas, tuamu and other vegetables. They will use their loans to purchase a weed killing sprayer, chemicals, knives, knife sharpeners and laborers.

Soonalau T., age 42, married, with ten children, sells raw fish to the people in her village and at the market five days per week. Her husband has been catching the fish for over three years. She will use her loan to purchase a flashlight, goggles and other fishing equipment.

loans.use: To purchase farming and fishing equipment

loans.name: Lucy's Group

texts.es:
Floriza, Lucy and Rosa have belonged to the “Nobleza” Communal Bank for one year, eight months and five years, respectively.

Floriza is 29 years old and has one child. She travels to the fairs where she buys animals and later sells the meat from a stand in the F. Vivanco Market. Besides that, Floriza grows potatoes on her land in Chiara and sells them in the markets of Ayacucho.

Lucy is a 30-year-old single mother with two children. She makes woven blankets and rugs that she sells in the market in Santa Clara. She also sells cheese in the same market.

Rosa is 51 years old, married and has five children. She makes ice cream with the help of her children and then sells both from home and in the fairs. In addition to that, Rosa buys cheeses and cereals in the fairs that she then sells to the stores in the city of Ayacucho.

Floriza, Lucy and Rosa need a loan of $825. With the money they will purchase sheep, goats, thread, dyes, barquillos (typical snack) and milk. The dreams of these three women are to have their own home, grow their businesses and to provide good nutrition and education for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Floriza, Lucy y Rosa pertenecen al Banco Comunal Nobleza hace 1 año, 8 meses, 5 años, respectivamente.

Floriza es conviviente, tiene 29 años y 1 hijo, Floriza vende carne en un puesto del mercado F. Vivanco, Floriza viaja a las ferias donde compra los animales y posteriormente los beneficia. Además Floriza se dedica a la agricultura de papa en sus terrenos de Chiara, productos que vende en los mercados de Ayacucho.

Por otro lado Lucy es madre soltera, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Lucy realiza trabajos de tejidos en telar como frazadas, pisos, que vende en el mercado Santa Clara. Además Lucy vende quesos de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Santa Clara.

Mientras que Rosa es casada, tiene 51 años y 5 hijos, Rosa elabora helados con ayuda de sus hijos, sus ventas lo realiza en su casa y también en las ferias. Además Rosa de las ferias compra quesos, cereales que vende a las tiendas de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Floriza, Lucy y Rosa necesitan préstamos de 800 soles, 600 soles, 800 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de ganado ovino, caprino, hilos, tintes, barquillos, leche y colorantes.

Los sueños de Floriza, Lucy y Rosa son tener una casa propia, surtir más su negocio, brindar una buena alimentación y educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase sheep, goats, thread, dyes, barquillos (typical snack) and milk

loans.name: Min

texts.en:
Mrs. Min T., 49, a mother of seven children, works on her plot of farmland growing rice, vegetables, and fruit. She has been doing this for over 15 years and she can typically earn an average of $4 (USD) each day in revenue.

Her husband has worked as a mechanic in BathamBong province since 2001. He must live away from home for his job, but returns to the family home twice a month. One of her 7 children is employed by a garment factory, one sells mechanical tools, one is married and lives on his own, and the rest are unemployed.

After learning about CREIDIT from one of her neighbors, Min T. has applied for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase a hand-tractor to plow her farm and to help with other farming work.

loans.use: To purcahse a hand-tractor to plow her farmland.

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina works in a very successful womens' clothing business. She operates a sales location where she offers a selection of trendy knitted womens' apparel that is always in demand. Galina’s business has a long history.  She was able to start this new venture by accessing a loan. Since that time, her business has done quite well. She earns approximately $500 of profit each month. 
Galina has requested an additional loan to give her more working capital. 
(Note: this is a short term “express” loan that will be paid back in one month.)

loans.use: to purchase assorted inventory
